BROKER AND COMPANY LICENSES
Issuance of broker licenses
Company and branch office licenses
Responsibilities of qualifying broker
Broker supervision
Termination of qualifying broker status
Qualifying broker for more than one company
Temporary qualifying broker
Place of business
Teams
All Alabama real estate salesperson and broker licenses are registered to a
specific real estate office. Any individual wishing to be licensed as a broker in
Alabama must apply for a broker's license using an AREC-designated form
which specifies the real estate office under which the individual is registered.
The individual must also meet the education, experience, and personal
requirements for becoming an Alabama broker.
Issuance of broker
licenses General requirements. Individuals who want to obtain an Alabama real estate
broker license must meet the same personal requirements as those necessary to
obtain a salesperson license. An applicant must be
 a U.S. citizen or permanent resident alien, or be legally present in
the U.S.
 at least 19 years old
 a high school graduate or the equivalent
 a resident of any U.S. state
 free of any conviction for a felony or a crime involving moral
turpitude
 free of any rejection of a real estate license application or
revocation of a real estate license in any state within the previous 2
years
460 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

The broker applicant must provide the same documentation an applicant for a
salesperson license must provide (as discussed in detail in the previous chapter)
as proof of meeting these requirements.
Criminal background. Just as when applying for a salesperson license, if the
applicant has been convicted of a felony or a crime involving moral turpitude, he
or she may file an "Application for Determination of Licensing Eligibility" form
with the Commission. The Commission will review the conviction(s) and
determine if the applicant is eligible for licensure in Alabama.
Additionally, the AREC requires both state and national criminal history checks
to be performed on any applicant for licensure. The applicant must submit any
required information and fingerprints to the Commission, to the Federal Bureau
of Investigation, to the Alabama State Law Enforcement Agency or its successor,
or to a fingerprint processing service approved by the Commission. Fingerprints
are to be submitted on the approved fingerprint card.
The AREC may then use the criminal history to determine the qualifications and
fitness of the applicant to hold a real estate license. The applicant is responsible
for the cost of the criminal history check which must be current to the date of
license issuance.
Salesperson experience. The broker applicant also must have been licensed as
an active real estate salesperson in any state for at least 24 months before
applying for a broker license. The 24 months of licensure must have occurred
within the 36 months prior to applying for the Alabama broker license. Proof of
this licensure must be submitted to the Commission along with the broker license
application.
Coursework and state examination. Additionally, the broker applicant must
complete a 60-hour AREC-approved broker pre-license real estate course.
After the applicant has met all requirements, he or she must apply to take the
national and state broker licensure examination, pay the examination fee, and
pass the examination with a score of at least 70%. The examination must be taken
and passed within 6 months of course completion.
When the applicant has met all requirements, including passing the examination,
he or she will apply for the broker license. Once the broker license is issued, the
broker's salesperson's license automatically terminates. The salesperson's license
certificate is to be returned to the Commission for the broker's license to be
issued.
An applicant for a broker's license must maintain a place of business.
Associate broker status. According to Alabama license law, all brokers must be
registered to a real estate business and under the business's qualifying broker.
Once registered, the broker becomes an associate broker with that qualifying
broker. By definition, an associate broker is any broker other than a qualifying
broker, made so by his or her relationship with the qualifying broker.
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 461

Company and
branch office
licenses The Alabama Real Estate Commission defines a company as "any sole
proprietorship, corporation, partnership, branch office, or lawfully constituted
business organization as the Legislature may provide from time to time."
Corporations, LLCs, and sole proprietorships are the most common examples of
companies under Alabama law. The other common entity defined as a company
is a branch office. Alabama license law requires every qualifying broker and
every place of business to have a company license.
License application. The company's qualifying broker is responsible for
applying for a company license or branch office license. The application must be
made on an AREC-approved form. Branch office licenses use a special
application form because the law requires that the branch qualifying broker and
the main company qualifying broker both share responsibility for the actions at
the branch office.
The qualifying broker is required to be an officer, partner, or employee of the
company.
The company license applicant must maintain a place of business. If the applicant
maintains more than one place of business in Alabama, he or she needs a
company or branch office license for each location or branch office. The
company must meet the following requirements for licensure:
 the application must include the location of the company or branch
office and the name of its qualifying broker
 each company or branch office must be under the direction and
supervision of a qualifying broker who is licensed at the company
or branch office address
 each company or branch office must have its own qualifying broker
with no qualifying broker serving more than one location
 the branch office qualifying broker and the company qualifying
broker are to share equal responsibility for the activities of all
licensees assigned to the branch office or company
Every activity that requires a real estate license must be performed in the name of
the licensed company under the qualifying broker. If the qualifying broker
declines to support certain types of business activities, the salespersons and
brokers working for that company must not engage in those activities.
For example, let's say that qualifying broker Bob does not want to include
property management in the services offered by his company. Bob has several
associate brokers who want to manage property, so they decide to manage
property on their own and not under Bob. Bob has told them he doesn't care as
long as he doesn't have to deal with the activities. Bob has also told them that
they cannot use the company name when offering and performing the property
management services.
This seems workable for all involved, right? However, it is against Alabama
license law because every activity a licensee performs must be performed in the
name of the licensed company and under the qualifying broker. Therefore, the
462 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

associate brokers may not manage property unless Bob agrees to include that
service in his company offerings so the brokers can manage property in Bob's
company name and under Bob.
Each company license expires at midnight on September 30 of the final year of
the license period.
Qualifying broker requirements. To serve as a qualifying broker, the
individual must be an Alabama-licensed broker with real estate being his or her
principal business. The individual must also be in a position to supervise the real
estate activities of any associate broker or salesperson registered to that office.
Serving as a qualifying broker is a full time position, so the individual must be
available to serve full time.
Responsibilities of
qualifying broker Salespersons and associate brokers must be licensed under a qualifying broker
who is then responsible for real estate activities in which the salesperson or
associate broker engage. The qualifying broker is also responsible for all real
estate activities of the company for which he or she is the qualifying broker.
The qualifying broker must also assure that all transactions performed by any
licensee or company for which he or she is responsible comply with Alabama
license law and AREC rules.
If a licensee or company for which the qualifying broker is responsible violates
any of these laws or rules, the qualifying broker will be held responsible to the
injured party for any damage caused by the violation. The qualifying broker's
liability will be in addition to the licensee's own liability for such violations.
The qualifying broker is also responsible for displaying the current licenses for
all companies, branch offices, brokers, and salespersons under his or her
supervision. The licenses must be publicly displayed at the place of business.
Even though the law requires the qualifying broker to supervise the associate
brokers and salespersons licensed under him or her, the law is not meant to
establish an employer-employee relationship. The broker and licensee may
establish such a relationship, but the law does not automatically establish it for
them.
Broker supervision One of the primary responsibilities of a qualifying broker is proper supervision of
the broker’s company and of those licensed under the broker. Proper supervision
includes, but is not limited to, the following:
1) maintain an active broker’s license with the Commission
2) prevent unlicensed persons from engaging in activities requiring a license on
behalf of the qualifying broker or company
3) prevent a licensee from conducting licensed activity for a company under
which the licensee is not licensed
4) prevent a person whose license is expired, inactive, pending transfer
suspended, or revoked from engaging in licensed activities
5) ensure that licensees comply with any restrictions placed on their licenses
6) refrain from causing licensees to violate a state, federal, or local law or
regulation while conducting licensed activity
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 463

7) prevent licensees from violating state, federal, local or license law while
conducting licensed activity when the broker knows or should know of the
impending violation
8) take timely action to correct or mitigate a violation of license law or
regulation on learning of the violation
9) ensure that contracts and forms used by licensees are accurate and in
compliance with statutes, rules, and office policies.
10) ensure that licensees are able to communicate effectively with the
supervising broker, branch broker, or a competent designee
11) ensure that the company and its licensees handle funds and other property
belonging to others properly
12) ensure that the company’s advertisements and those of its licensees conform
with license laws and rules
13) provide necessary orientation for licensees newly affiliated with the
company.
Termination of
qualifying broker
status An individual may change his or her status as qualifying broker for a licensee by
notifying the licensee and the Commission in writing. Remember, each licensee
must be registered under a qualifying broker. So, if the qualifying broker wants to
cease being a licensee's qualifying broker, he or she must send the licensee's
license certificate back to the Commission. The Commission will then issue a
new license certificate registered to a new qualifying broker. If the license has
been lost or destroyed, the qualifying broker must verify that in writing to the
Commission.
An individual may terminate his or her status as a qualifying broker for a
company by providing written notice to the company or to the qualifying broker
of the parent company. He or she must also notify the Commission.
Licensees and companies whose qualifying broker has terminated his or her
status as such may not perform any acts for which a license is required until a
relationship with a new qualifying broker has been established and a new active
license has been issued by the Commission.
Qualifying broker
for more than one
company Brokers may not serve as the qualifying broker for more than one company or for
a company and him or herself unless the following requirements are met:
 the qualifying broker must obtain the written consent of all
companies for which he or she wishes to serve
 the qualifying broker must file a copy of the written consent with
the commission
 all of the companies share the same company address
The qualifying broker's licensees may be engaged by one or all of the companies
for which the qualifying broker serves.
Temporary
qualifying broker Should a company's qualifying broker die or become disabled, the company
license will become invalid. Within 30 days of the qualifying broker's death or
disability, the corporation or the remaining partners may designate another
464 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

officer, member, or salesperson to apply for a license as a temporary qualifying
broker.
The person designated must be a broker or have been a licensed salesperson for at
least 1 year prior to the application being submitted. If the application is granted,
the company is allowed to operate under the temporary qualifying broker for no
more than 6 months from the date the commission issues the temporary
qualifying broker license. During that 6 months, the company must designate a
fully licensed broker as the qualifying broker.
If the company does not designate a fully licensed qualifying broker within 6
months of the commission issuing the temporary license, the company license
and all licenses under the company will be placed on inactive status by the
Commission after a 2-week notice.
Place of business Real estate professionals must maintain a place of business which is identified by
a sign that includes the name of the company as it is licensed with the AREC. If
exterior signs are allowed, the sign is to be posted outside the office so that it is
plainly and readily visible to the public. If exterior signs are not permitted, the
sign is to be posted inside the place of business and is to comply with the
building's restrictions on signage. If allowed, the sign should be posted in the
entry area and on the office door.
Licensees who are located within city limits or the police jurisdiction of a
municipality are to operate from an office also located in the city limits or police
jurisdiction. The office must be a separate space with a business telephone and a
sign identifying it as a real estate office.
All business records and files are to be kept at the place of business. Maintenance
of such records and files is to comply with Alabama law and AREC rules.
Operating from home. Licensed brokers who live in rural areas of Alabama may
operate from their homes as long as the broker sets up an office to be used
specifically for conducting real estate business. The space set up as an office may
not be used for living purposes.
The space also may only be used by the one broker and not by other licensees
who are operating under the broker's license. In other words, the broker may not
conduct business as a qualifying broker who supervises associate brokers
operating from the same home office space.
The home office space must have a separate business telephone, a separate
entrance, and a sign that identifies it as a real estate office.
Teams In many real estate companies, individual licensees team up with other
professionals to form an official team to provide real estate services. In Alabama,
a team is defined as two or more licensees who join forces to offer real estate
services as a distinct group. A real estate licensee may only be a member of one
team.
A team does not need to be registered as a separate entity with AREC. While the
qualifying broker designates the team leader, the qualifying broker cannot
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 465

delegate any duties reserved for qualifying brokers to that team leader. In
addition, the team leader must provide a list of team members to the qualifying
broker.
TRUST FUNDS
Purpose
Trust funds defined
Qualifying broker responsibilities
Disbursement of trust funds
Trust fund management
Trust fund scams
Escrow account reconciliation
A trust fund account, also known as an escrow account, is a bank account set up
to hold funds belonging to someone other than the real estate broker owning the
account. The account is set up by the brokerage company's qualifying broker at a
federally insured banking institution that is located in Alabama. The funds are
held until such a time that a specific event, such as a real estate closing, takes
place.
Purpose When a property is being purchased, the buyer provides earnest money to the
broker to be held until the purchase closes. These earnest funds are to be
deposited into a bank account other than the broker's business or personal
account.
This trust fund account keeps the client's money separate from the broker's
money. This ensures that any money the client needs to use for the real estate
transaction is in a secure account that is accessible only by the client or the
broker. As long as the money is held in a trust account in a bank insured by the
Federal Deposit Insurance Corporation (FDIC), each client's funds are insured up
to $250,000.
Trust funds defined Alabama license law and AREC rules require a real estate licensee to deposit and
account for all funds belonging to or being held for others at all times. These
funds include earnest money, security deposits, and all other funds related to a
contract for the sale or lease of property or a property management agreement.
They are money or other items of value that the broker receives on behalf of an
individual (usually the property buyer) to be held for the benefit of others in
relation to any acts for which a real estate license is required.
The funds may be U.S. currency (cash), checks, notes, other recognized forms of
money, or other items of value. Cash is to be deposited immediately. Checks may
be held for a specific length of time before being deposited if the purchase offer
designates the length of time or the event that must occur prior to the check being
deposited. If the offer does not state a specific time for the check to be deposited,
it is to be deposited when the offer becomes a contract.
466 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Each salesperson or associate broker must submit to his or her qualifying broker
all funds that come into the salesperson or broker's possession to be held for other
parties.
Qualifying broker
responsibilities Alabama laws and rules also require that the individual responsible for holding
trust funds is to be the qualifying broker.
The qualifying broker is responsible for depositing the funds belonging to others
to be held in trust unless he or she is expressly relieved of the responsibility in
writing. Thus, the qualifying broker is the trustee for the account.
If a purchase contract involves more than one qualifying broker, any of the
qualifying brokers involved in the sale may deposit and hold the funds related to
the purchase.
Funds being held in relation to a purchase contract, a lease, or a property
management agreement are to be deposited and held by the qualifying broker
who is providing these services to the property owner. If the services are
provided by a secondary or successor broker, the first broker is to provide a
complete accounting of the funds to the successor qualifying broker and is to
transfer the funds to the successor broker.
The qualifying broker who is currently providing the services to the owner is
responsible to the public and to the Commission for the funds. At the request of
the Commission, the current qualifying broker must immediately account for any
trust funds he or she holds.
The qualifying broker is to be a customer of the bank or financial institution
where the trust account is held and is to be one of the persons with authority to
deposit and withdraw funds from the account. He or she may write or make
checks as necessary on all trust accounts set up on behalf of the company.
Disbursement of
trust funds The qualifying broker holding the trust funds must disburse the funds to the
appropriate party or parties within 7 days of the consummation of the transaction
for which the funds were being held. In other words, when the purchase is
completed and closed, the funds must be disbursed within 7 days of that closing
date.
If the transaction does not close or there is disagreement regarding who should
receive the funds, the qualifying broker must not disburse any of the funds unless
there is a court order or until there is a written agreement signed by all parties.
Alternatively, the broker may deposit the funds with the appropriate court under
the rules of interpleader or any other lawful procedure that is applicable.
The rules of interpleader remove the qualifying broker from the disbursement
process and make the disagreeing parties litigate the disbursement between
themselves. The qualifying broker becomes the stakeholder, and the disagreeing
parties become the claimants. The stakeholder then would deposit the funds
under dispute with the court, and the court would decide who is legally entitled to
the funds. Thus, the qualifying broker is released from any liability regarding
disbursement of the funds.
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 467

Trust fund
management Proper accounting. Alabama license law has defined procedures which real
estate professionals must follow in relation to trust fund accounts. The law has
also assigned penalties for failing to perform any of these acts. The law requires
the licensee to properly account for or remit money belonging to others that
comes into his or her possession. Consequently, licensees must be able to
correctly determine the amount of trust funds they are holding. Failure to do so is
a violation of the law. The law also requires the broker to deposit and account for
all funds belonging to others or being held for others in a federally insured
account in a financial institution located in Alabama. Failure to do so is a
violation of the law.
No commingling. Further, the licensee is required to maintain trust accounts
separate from his or her personal or business accounts to hold funds belonging to
others. The trust account may hold funds belonging to multiple clients but not
funds belonging to the broker. Failure to separate the broker's funds from the
funds belonging to others is called commingling and is a violation of Alabama
law. However, the AREC does allow the broker to keep some personal funds in a
trust account to cover bank service charges or check fees.
The qualifying broker can lose his or her license if the broker uses any money
from the trust account for his own personal or business use.
The broker is not only responsible for his or her own actions, but also for the
actions of the salespersons and brokers which the qualifying broker supervises.
Thus, the qualifying broker may be held responsible for any commingling,
embezzling, and conversion of his or her client's money committed by associate
brokers or salespersons.
Violations and discipline. If a licensee violates any of these provisions of the
law pertaining to trust funds and the violation is reported in writing to the AREC,
the Commission or its staff may investigate the actions and records of the
licensee. Just as with any other violation or complaint, the Commission may issue
subpoenas and hear testimony of witnesses and require trust fund records and
documents to be produced during the course of the investigation.
If the Commission finds probable cause as a result of the investigation, the
Commission will file a formal complaint and hold a hearing on the complaint. If
the hearing determines the licensee is guilty of an alleged trust fund violation, the
Commission will impose any or all of the following penalties for each act for
which the licensee is found guilty:
 require the licensee to complete continuing education courses in
addition to the existing CE requirements
 suspend or revoke the licensee's license
 impose a fine of at least $100 but not more than $5,000
 suspend or revoke the license and impose a fine
 reprimand the licensee
The Commission may suspend or revoke the license until the licensee has
completed an approved continuing education course and/or made restitution to
468 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

any accounts holding funds that belong to others. The Commission may also stay
the revocation or suspension and require the licensee to complete an approved
education course and/or make restitution to any accounts holding funds belonging
to others.
Trust fund scams In this age of technology, it is common for funds to be transferred and deposited
into bank accounts by way of electronic transfers. However, it is also
unfortunately common for electronic hackers and scammers to use the same
transfer methods to commit email and wire fraud and obtain funds belonging to
others.
The scammer typically hacks into an email account or impersonates the email of
a party involved in a real estate transaction. Once the scammer has the email of
the involved party, the scammer transmits false wiring information for the
transfer of funds from the real estate transaction. The funds then are wired to the
scammer's bank account and then immediately transferred to a bank out of the
country, making it impossible to recover the funds. Typically, neither the
scammer's bank or the victim's bank will reimburse the funds.
Scammers are targeting licensees, parties to transactions, and even real estate
settlement agents in Alabama and across the U.S. The following tips will help
protect involved parties from falling victim to these scammers:
 never send wire transfer information or any sensitive information
by email. this includes bank information or routing numbers
 include statements in emails that wiring instructions will not be sent
by email
 inform parties involved in the transaction of the scam and ask they
inform the licensee of any requests involving funds transfers
 if funds must be wired, contact the intended recipient on the phone
and inform them of the intended transfer
 do not open suspicious emails or click on suspicious links
 be very careful with callers who request username or password
verification
 use passwords that are not easy to guess and then change them on a
regular basis
 keep firewall and antivirus software up to date
While hackers and scammers are becoming more and more sophisticated on ways
to obtain bank account information, often times simple steps and common sense
can thwart their efforts.
Escrow account
reconciliation As the trust account holder, the qualifying broker is responsible for depositing
and accounting for all trust funds in the account. Accounting for the funds
requires periodic reconciliation of the broker's records with those of the bank
holding the accounts.
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 469

All deposits into and disbursements from the trust account should be indicated
both in the broker's records and on account statements from the bank. Any
discrepancies must be accounted for and resolved.
Trust fund recordkeeping. All records pertaining to funds belonging to others
must be maintained for at least 3 years. The records must indicate to whom the
money belongs, the date the money was deposited, the date the money was
withdrawn or disbursed, and any other pertinent information.
Reconciliation. The AREC suggests the following as means to reconcile the
account records with the bank records:
 tape canceled checks into the checkbook next to the check stub to
maintain a complete record of the check without having to search
statements for the check in question
 prepare a continuous list of pending contracts with the amount of
earnest money involved. mark off each transaction as it closes, as
the money is refunded, or as it is forfeited by the buyer or seller
 deduct any bank service charges from the account before the
remainder of the commission is paid to prevent overdraft charges.
the AREC allows additional designated funds to be deposited into
the account to cover bad checks, services charges, etc.
 keep pending contracts separate from closed contracts
 maintain a separate escrow account for rental or leased property to
distinguish it from sales contracts which will have no
disbursements for repairs, owner's payments, etc.
 keep written receipts of all funds that are received, whether they are
cash, check, or other items of value. doing so will provide an
internal means of control
While Alabama law does not designate a time frame for account reconciliation,
monthly reconciliations are a good course of action to maintain accurate records
and to stay on top of discrepancies. Balancing the company's account records
against the bank statement should be performed as soon as the statement is
received.
If the funds being held are security deposits or rent payments, the licensee should
maintain a security deposit escrow account and a rent escrow account to hold the
funds belonging to the tenants or to the property owner.
The licensee should maintain a continuous ledger that includes all deposits, the
tenants' names, the property address, the owner's name, the deposit amount, and
the date of the deposit. Account ledgers for rent payments should also include a
record of payments to the property owner as proceeds, to the real estate
management company for their management fees, and invoices for any
maintenance.
These accounts also should be reconciled monthly with the balances shown in the
ledgers matching with the balances shown on the monthly bank statement for
each account.
470 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

ESTIMATED CLOSING STATEMENT
Purpose for the estimate
Estimated closing expenditures
Disclosure to consumer
A real estate closing is the transfer of the property title from the seller to the
buyer in accordance with the sales contract. However, there are numerous costs
associated with the closing that can become quite complex. The costs involved
are determined by the sales contract, local tradition and custom, type of
financing, and local, state, and federal laws.
The closing statement. A closing statement is an accounting document used in
the real estate transaction closing that details the final costs related to a transfer of
ownership of property. It is also known as a settlement statement.
While the closing statement presents the final settlement costs, buyers and sellers
need to know the approximate transaction costs at the time an offer to purchase
the property is made. Therefore, the law requires that an estimated closing
statement be produced for both the buyer and the seller at the time an offer or
counteroffer is made. The estimate approximates settlement costs so that each
party will be duly informed and prepared. All parties to the transaction should
compare the estimated closing statement to the final closing statement to find and
correct potential errors.
Providing an estimated closing statement to the buyer and seller also helps
protect against mortgage fraud by eliminating the potential for unexpected and/or
unexplained costs charged by the bank or mortgage company at the actual
closing.
Purpose for
the estimate Any licensee who represents a residential buyer and obtains a written purchase
offer must prepare and provide an estimated closing statement to the buyer. The
statement must contain the most accurate and complete estimates of all costs that
are the buyer's responsibility at the time the transaction closes. The statement
must itemize not only which costs the buyer will pay but also the estimated
amount of each cost. The licensee must provide the statement to the buyer at the
time the buyer signs the offer to purchase.
Any licensee who represents a residential seller and presents a written purchase
offer to such seller must also prepare and provide an estimated closing statement
to the seller. The statement provided to the seller must show which costs are the
seller's responsibilities and approximately how much each of those costs will be.
This statement is to be provided to the seller at the time the offer is presented.
By signing the estimated and the actual closing statements, both the buyer and the
seller are acknowledging that they received the statements.
TILA, RESPA and TRID. Alabama license law and administrative rules
protect the consumer by mandating that licensee provide an estimated closing
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 471

statement. At the same time, the Truth in Lending Act (TILA) and the Real Estate
Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) also serve to protect the consumer. TILA-
RESPA Integrated Disclosure (TRID) Rules have specific requirements for
disclosure notices from the lender of a mortgage loan to the borrower.
Under TRID, the Good Faith Estimate formerly provided by lenders has been
replaced by the Loan Estimate, which must be provided to the borrower of a
mortgage loan within 3 business days of the borrower's application for the loan.
Additionally, a TRID-mandated Closing Disclosure must be provided to the
borrower 3 days prior to closing on the mortgage loan.
Keep in mind the difference in these mandated disclosures:
 the estimated closing statement, mandated by Alabama law, is
provided by the real estate licensee to inform the buyer and the
seller of all costs associated to the real estate transaction closing; it
is provided at the time a purchase offer or counter offer is submitted
 the loan estimate and closing disclosure, mandated by federal law,
are provided by the lender to inform the borrower of the costs
associated with the mortgage loan; the loan estimate is provided at
the time the loan application is received, and the closing disclosure
is three days prior to closing, as stated
Both federal and state laws work to assure the consumer is informed, prepared,
and protected in real estate transactions and financing.
Estimated closing
expenditures The estimated closing statement includes debits and credits for both the seller and
the buyer that are due at closing and the approximate amount of each. Typically,
what is a debit to the seller is a credit to the buyer and vice versa.
Debits for the seller would include the following:
 real estate commissions to be paid
 escrow fees
 excise taxes, if applicable
 repairs to be done based on the home inspection
 prorated property taxes and assessments
 title clearing
 second mortgages, home equity loans, and tax liens
 any other items to be paid by the seller
 credits for the seller would include the following:
 purchase price of the property
 prorated prepaid property insurance
 prorated prepaid utilities
 prorated prepaid property taxes
 any other agreed upon shared costs between the buyer and seller
472 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

Debits for the buyer would include the following:
 purchase price of the property
 escrow fees
 title insurance
 mortgage loan origination fee
 home inspections
 property surveys
 prorated prepaid property insurance
 prorated prepaid utilities
 prorated prepaid property taxes
 any other items to be paid by the buyer
Credits for the buyer would include the following:
 earnest money deposit
 cash down payment
 adjustments for the buyer's overpayment of estimated attorney fees
and closing costs
 repairs needed based on the home inspection but not prepaid by the
seller
 any other agreed upon shared costs between the buyer and seller
Disclosure to
consumer The Real Estate Settlement Procedures Act (RESPA) requires that the buyer of
real estate be informed about closing costs and prevents abusive practices that
inflate the costs of closing for the buyer. The Act requires that the lender disclose
the costs of closing to the borrower and prohibits the lender from demanding
excessive deposits for escrow accounts.
Providing an estimated closing statement is the means for disclosing purchasing
or sellings costs that the buyer or seller will be expected to pay. Because the
notification must take place at the time an offer to purchase is obtained from the
buyer or presented to the seller, it assures there will be no surprises for either
party at closing.
Failing to disclose these estimated costs to the buyer or the seller is a violation of
Alabama license law and RESPA and puts the licensee at risk of investigation by
the AREC. If found guilty at a formal hearing, the licensee may have his or her
license suspended or revoked, may have a $100 to $5,000 fine imposed, may be
reprimanded for each instance of a guilty verdict. The licensee may also be
required to complete an approved continuing education course and/or make
restitution.
Chapter 27: Alabama Brokerage Regulation 473

ADVERTISING
Advertising with an interest
Signage
Team Advertising
When advertising real estate, licensees must be honest. They are prohibited from
making false promises that could potentially influence, persuade, or induce a
consumer to enter into a contract. They are also prohibited from flagrant
misrepresentation in any form of advertising. Publishing any advertisement that
deceives the public or is likely to deceive the public is against the law. All
advertisements must identify the advertiser as a licensed broker or salesperson.
Advertising with an
interest Alabama license law exempts property owners from licensing requirements
when the owners are managing their own property or engaging in a real estate
transaction involving their own property. In other words, a property owner can
manage, lease, or sell his or her own property without needing to be licensed as a
real estate salesperson or broker. This also means the property owner can
advertise his or her own property for lease or sale without needing to be licensed.
Alabama license law also allows any property owner who becomes a licensed
broker or salesperson to advertise his or her own property. However, while the
non-licensed owner is exempt from the license laws, the licensed owner must
abide by all provisions of the law and AREC rules in any real estate transaction.
This includes transactions in which the licensee is the property owner or the
spouse, child, or parent of the property owner.
Thus, the licensee must also comply with all applicable laws when advertising his
or her own property for lease or sale.
Further, if the licensee is advertising his or her own property or property
belonging to a member of the licensee's immediate family, the licensee must
provide prior written disclosure of his or her interest in the property to all parties
to the transaction. The licensee must also disclose that he or she is a licensed real
estate salesperson or broker. The law states the disclosure must be "timely"
without giving a definitive time frame.
If the licensee is seeking to purchase an interest in a property being sold by his or
her brokerage company, the licensee must disclose his or her intention to the
property seller or the seller's agent. The licensee must inform the seller that he or
she is a licensed real estate salesperson or broker and that he or she is the
intended buyer of the property.
Signage Real estate licensees have the legal right to advertise property for sale, lease, or
transfer using signs that are affixed to or located on the property itself. Alabama
does not allow a municipal corporation or local government to impose a fee or
tax on the signs, whether the signs are located on or near the property.
However, local, county and city governments are allowed to set and enforce
reasonable restrictions on the size, height, and placement of signs on private
474 Principles of Real Estate Practice in Alabama

property or a public right-of-way. Such restrictions are covered in detail in
Article 1 of Chapter 54 of the Alabama Code of Ordinances. The restrictions
include the manner of erection and posting of signs, interference or obstructions
caused by the signs, removal and disposal of the signs, etc.
Team Advertising Real estate teams have specific advertising rules that apply only to them. While
the law has granted AREC the ability to adopt rules regarding the words that may
and may not be used in team names and how teams may market and advertise
their services, the law does proscribe a few of its own requirements.
In team advertisements, the name of at least one team member and the name of
the real estate company where the team members are licensed must both be
included in the ad. Either “team” or “group” must be included in the team name.
In addition, the qualifying broker must give written authorization to allow the
team to include its name in any advertisements.
RECORDKEEPING
Both estimated closing statements and the actual closing statements must be
retained in the broker's files. The buyer's agent should retain the estimated and
actual closing statements signed by the buyer in his or her qualifying broker's
files, while the seller's agent retains the statements signed by the seller. Neither
licensee is required to retain statements signed by both the buyer and the seller.
Nor is it necessary for cooperating brokers to maintain both the buyer's statement
and the seller's statement.
Although the law does not specify a time frame for retention of closing
statements, as with any documents or records related to a real estate transaction,
the statements should be retained for at least 3 years.

qualifying broker ● every qualifying broker must be an Alabama-licensed broker with real estate as
the principal business

● the qualifying broker must display all current licenses for the company, brokers,

Broker supervision ● qualifying broker must supervise company and its licensees

Termination ● the qualifying broker may terminate his or her status for a licensee by notifying

company ● qualifying brokers may serve only one company at a time unless he or she has the

TRUST FUNDS
Purpose ● a trust account is a bank account set up to hold any funds belonging to others and
is set up by the qualifying broker at a federally insured bank in Alabama
● trust accounts keep client funds separate from the broker's own funds
● federally insured accounts insure funds up to $250,000
Trust funds defined ● all funds belonging to others must be held in a trust account
● includes earnest money or other funds related to a real estate transaction
● includes cash, checks, notes, other recognized forms of money, or other items of
value
● cash is to be deposited immediately; checks may be held for a length of time
specified in the purchase offer or when the offer becomes a contract
● salespersons and brokers must submit all funds to the qualifying broker for deposit
into a trust account
Qualifying broker
responsibilities ● the qualifying broker is required by Alabama law to hold all trust funds
● the qualifying broker must deposit all trust funds unless relieved of the
responsibility in writing
● with multiple qualifying brokers, any of the involved qualifying brokers may
deposit and hold the funds
● funds are held by qualifying broker who is providing services
● when services are provided by a secondary broker, the first broker must provide a
complete accounting of all funds to the secondary broker and must transfer the
funds to the secondary broker
● qualifying broker providing the services to the owner is also responsible to the
public and the AREC for the funds and must immediately account for the funds
upon the AREC's request
● the qualifying broker must be a customer at the bank where the trust account is
maintained
● the qualifying broker must also have authority to deposit and withdraw the funds
and may do so by writing or making checks as necessary
Disbursement of trust
funds ● the qualifying broker must disburse funds to the appropriate party within 7 days of
the closing of the transaction
● the qualifying broker must not disburse funds if there is no closing or if there is a
disagreement as to whom should receive the funds
● the qualifying broker must have a written agreement signed by all parties or a
court order to release funds in the case of a disagreement
● the qualifying broker may deposit funds with the appropriate court if there is a
disbursement disagreement
Trust fund management ● licensees must properly account for or remit money belonging to others and must
be able to determine the amount of funds being held
● licensees must deposit and account for all funds belong to others and must use a
federally insured account in an institution located in Alabama
● licensees must not commingle trust funds with broker's own funds but may keep
personal funds in the trust account to cover service charges
● the qualifying broker must not use any trust funds for personal use
● the qualifying broker is responsible for actions of associated salespersons and
brokers in relation to trust funds

Trust fund scams ● hackers and scammers are using email to commit wire fraud
● once the funds are transferred to the scammer's bank and then out of the country,
most banks will not reimburse the monies
● there are several ways involved parties can thwart the scammers, such as changing
email passwords often, not sending wire transfer information in emails, contacting
the intended recipient of wired funds on the phone
Trust fund
reconciliation ● Alabama law does not designate a time frame for account reconciliation, but
monthly reconciliations are recommended
● balancing the company's account records with the bank's statement should occur
as soon as the bank's statement is received
● all deposits and disbursements should show on both the broker's records and the
bank's statement with discrepancies resolved ASAP
● all trust fund records must be kept for 3 years
● records must show to whom the money belongs, the deposit and withdrawal dates,
and any other pertinent information
● AREC recommended reconciliation includes: taping canceled checks into the

ESTIMATED CLOSING
STATEMENT
Purpose ● the closing statement details the costs related to the transfer of property ownership.
● the estimated closing statement approximates closing costs so each party is
informed and prepared.
● an estimated closing statement helps protect the consumer against mortgage fraud
● licensees must provide an estimated closing statement to any buyer who submits a
written purchase offer for a single family residential property, with the statement
including each cost the buyer will pay and the estimated amount of each cost; the
statement is due at the time the buyer signs the purchase offer.
● licensees must provide an estimated closing statement to any seller at the time a
written purchase offer is presented, with the statement including each cost the
seller will pay and the estimated amount of each cost.
● licensees must provide an actual closing statement to both the buyer and the seller
when the sale closes, with the statement showing all receipts and disbursements.
● the buyer and seller acknowledge receiving the statements by signing both the
estimated and the actual closing statements.
Estimated closing
expenditures ● a debit to the seller is a credit to the buyer and vice versa.
